target_audience.primary_persona: AI researchers and developers experimenting with GitHub Copilot's agentic capabilities to understand how AI assistants can autonomously handle complex, multi-step software development workflows
secondary_personas: Engineering teams exploring AI-assisted development patterns and best practices
GitHub Copilot power users seeking advanced prompting strategies and instruction patterns
Developers interested in code migration and refactoring automation techniques
pain_points: Difficulty understanding how to effectively delegate complex, multi-step tasks to AI coding assistants
Lack of established patterns for structuring instructions that enable autonomous AI agent workflows
Unclear how to maintain context across multiple AI-driven development sessions
Need for reusable frameworks to guide AI assistants in planning, discovery, and implementation tasks
Uncertainty about best practices for capturing and documenting AI-assisted development processes
goals: Discover effective patterns for agentic AI workflows in software development
Establish reusable instruction frameworks that enable autonomous task execution
Document learnings and best practices for working with AI coding assistants
Build portable agent skills that can be reused across projects
Create comprehensive planning artifacts that serve as living documentation
target_audience.usage_context: Developers and researchers use this project as an experimental testbed when exploring how GitHub Copilot can handle autonomous planning, roadmap generation, feature implementation, and code migration tasks with structured instruction files and agent-based workflows

product_vision.one_liner: An experimental framework for testing and documenting GitHub Copilot's agentic capabilities through structured multi-agent workflows and reusable instruction patterns
product_vision.problem_statement: AI coding assistants like GitHub Copilot have powerful capabilities, but there's limited understanding of how to structure instructions and workflows to enable autonomous, multi-step task execution. Developers need patterns and frameworks to effectively delegate complex planning, analysis, and implementation tasks to AI agents.
product_vision.value_proposition: Provides a structured, documented approach to building agentic AI workflows with reusable agent definitions, skills, and instruction patterns that enable autonomous task execution while maintaining quality and capturing institutional knowledge through planning artifacts
success_metrics: Number of reusable agent skills successfully created and documented
Effectiveness of autonomous workflows (measured by task completion without human intervention)
Quality and comprehensiveness of generated planning artifacts
Community adoption and contribution to agent patterns and skills
Documentation completeness covering learnings, patterns, and best practices

existing_features: Orchestrator Agent for multi-agent workflow coordination
Planner Agent for autonomous implementation planning with subtask decomposition
Roadmap Discovery Agent for autonomous project analysis and understanding
Roadmap Features Agent for strategic feature generation and prioritization
Agent Skills Framework with progressive loading and bundled resources
Subtask Planning Skill with workflow classification (feature, refactor, investigation, migration, simple)
Project Discovery Skill for non-interactive codebase analysis
Feature Planning Skill with MoSCoW prioritization and priority matrix
Structured instruction files for each agent (planner, discovery, features, orchestrator)
Documentation-first approach with planning artifacts as first-class documentation
Comprehensive agent definitions with capabilities, I/O specs, and integration points
Multi-phase workflows for roadmap generation (discovery → features → implementation)
known_gaps: No actual code implementation agents - framework is currently documentation and planning only
Missing competitor analysis integration (referenced but not fully implemented)
No automated testing or validation of agent outputs
Limited examples of completed multi-agent workflows from start to finish
No metrics collection or analysis of agent effectiveness
Missing templates for common project types (web apps, CLIs, libraries)
No integration with external tools or APIs for enhanced analysis
Limited guidance on customizing agents for domain-specific needs
technical_debt: Agent definitions reference features not yet implemented (e.g., competitor_analysis.json generation)
Some documentation inconsistencies between agent definitions and prompt templates
No validation scripts to ensure agent outputs conform to schemas
Missing error handling and retry logic in workflow orchestration
No centralized configuration for agent behavior customization

alternatives: Auto-Claude - Autonomous Claude-based development framework (direct inspiration)
LangChain Agents - Framework for building autonomous AI agent applications
AutoGPT - Autonomous GPT-4 agent for task completion
GitHub Copilot Workspace - GitHub's official multi-file editing and planning workspace
Cursor IDE - AI-first code editor with multi-file context and agent capabilities
MetaGPT - Multi-agent framework for software development
Manual prompting strategies - Ad-hoc instruction crafting without structured frameworks
differentiators: Specifically designed for GitHub Copilot rather than general LLM agents
Documentation-first approach treats planning artifacts as first-class deliverables
Progressive loading architecture prevents context bloat while enabling unlimited skills
Non-interactive autonomous execution mode for discovery and analysis agents
Modular agent skill system inspired by agentskills.io specification
Comprehensive instruction templates with phase-by-phase execution guides
Focus on experimentation and learning documentation rather than production tooling
Multi-agent orchestration with explicit user approval gates between phases
competitive_context.market_position: Experimental research project and learning framework rather than production-ready tool, focused on documenting patterns and best practices for agentic AI development workflows within the GitHub Copilot ecosystem

technical: Dependent on GitHub Copilot's capabilities and limitations
Markdown and JSON-based system limits automation possibilities
No code execution environment - relies on documentation and instructions
Context window limitations require progressive loading and modular design
Limited to file-based workflows without external API integrations
resources: Single primary maintainer (Pradeep Patil) with Copilot assistance
Experimental project with no dedicated budget or timeline
Community contributions welcome but not actively solicited
dependencies: GitHub Copilot availability and API access
Git for version control and collaboration
JSON schema validation tools (not yet integrated)
GitHub repository hosting for version control and sharing
